statement.text: Hypothermic circulatory arrest (HCA) is a technique enabling complex aortic arch surgery by cooling the patient to temperatures that reduce cerebral metabolic demand, permitting safe cessation of circulation for a limited period. By reducing metabolic rate approximately 6-7% per degree Celsius, deep hypothermia (14-20°C) extends safe circulatory arrest time to 30-45 minutes. Modern approaches incorporate selective antegrade cerebral perfusion (SACP) or retrograde cerebral perfusion (RCP) to further extend safe arrest times and improve neurologic outcomes.
statement.formal: HCA: Core cooling via cardiopulmonary bypass to deep (14-20°C), moderate (20-28°C), or mild (28-34°C) hypothermia, reducing metabolic rate to permit circulatory arrest. SACP/RCP adjuncts extend safe arrest duration beyond 40-60 minutes.

explanation.intuition: When you cool something down, its chemical reactions slow dramatically. The brain, with its constant need for oxygen and glucose, is particularly vulnerable to blood flow interruption. By cooling the body like putting it in a 'biological refrigerator,' we dramatically slow the brain's metabolism so it needs much less oxygen. This buys surgeons time to work on the aortic arch without blood flow, similar to how cold water allows a person to survive drowning longer than warm water would.
explanation.key_insight: The metabolic protection of hypothermia follows the Q10 principle: for every 10°C drop in temperature, metabolic rate decreases by approximately 50%. At 18°C, cerebral metabolic rate is reduced to roughly 15% of baseline, extending safe circulatory arrest from minutes to approximately 40-45 minutes. Adjunctive cerebral perfusion techniques (SACP) can extend this to over 60 minutes.
explanation.technical_details: The procedure requires full cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) with cooling typically achieved via the heat exchanger in the CPB circuit. Core temperature is monitored at multiple sites (nasopharyngeal, bladder/rectal, esophageal). Cooling and rewarming must be gradual (0.5-1°C per minute) to avoid temperature gradients and air emboli. EEG monitoring confirms electrocerebral silence (isoelectric) before circulatory arrest. Selective antegrade cerebral perfusion (SACP) via axillary or innominate artery cannulation provides continuous brain perfusion during arrest, allowing warmer temperatures (24-28°C) with reduced hypothermia-related complications.

deep_hypothermia.disadvantages: Coagulopathy, longer bypass time, inflammatory response

moderate_hypothermia.safe_arrest_time: 20-30 minutes without adjuncts, >60 min with SACP

mild_hypothermia.use: Routine cardiac surgery, not for circulatory arrest
mild_hypothermia.note: Insufficient for HCA without continuous perfusion

SACP.name: Selective Antegrade Cerebral Perfusion
SACP.technique: Perfusion via axillary/innominate cannulation to arch vessels
advantages: Improved neurologic outcomes vs HCA alone

RCP.name: Retrograde Cerebral Perfusion
RCP.technique: Perfusion via SVC at low pressure (20-25 mmHg)
RCP.mechanism: Uncertain - may provide metabolic support, flush emboli/air
RCP.current_role: Largely supplanted by SACP, still used in some centers

indications: Complex ascending aortic surgery requiring arch access

technique_sequence.step_1: Establish CPB with arterial cannulation (femoral, axillary, or innominate)
technique_sequence.step_2: Initiate cooling (gradient ≤10°C between perfusate and blood)
technique_sequence.step_3: Achieve target temperature (confirm with nasopharyngeal and rectal probes)
technique_sequence.step_4: Confirm EEG isoelectricity for deep HCA
technique_sequence.step_6: Initiate SACP if planned (via axillary or direct arch vessel cannulation)
technique_sequence.step_10: Wean from CPB once normothermic and hemodynamically stable

definition.@value: Technique for complex aortic surgery in which the patient is cooled on cardiopulmonary bypass to reduce metabolic demands, permitting safe temporary cessation of circulation for arch repair

sources.citation: Erbel R, et al. 2014 ESC Guidelines on the diagnosis and treatment of aortic diseases. Eur Heart J. 2014;35(41):2873-926.
Yan TD, et al. Systematic review and meta-analysis of deep hypothermic circulatory arrest versus moderate hypothermic circulatory arrest. Ann Cardiothorac Surg. 2013;2(2):148-58.
Cohn LH. Cardiac Surgery in the Adult, 5th Edition, Chapter 32

learning_objectives: Explain the metabolic rationale for hypothermic circulatory arrest
Compare temperature strategies (deep, moderate, mild hypothermia)
Describe the technique of selective antegrade cerebral perfusion
Understand the limitations of retrograde cerebral perfusion
Outline the technical sequence for HCA with SACP
Recognize neurologic and systemic complications of HCA
clinical_pearls: Metabolic rate decreases ~50% for every 10°C drop in temperature (Q10 effect)
Safe HCA time at 18°C is approximately 40-45 minutes without adjuncts
SACP extends safe time to >60 minutes and allows warmer temperatures
EEG isoelectricity confirms adequate cerebral metabolic suppression
Rewarming too fast causes temperature gradients and increases stroke risk
Avoid rewarming above 37°C - cerebral hyperthermia worsens outcomes

medicalCode.description: Repair of thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm with graft, with or without bypass
